How to Calculate Subfloor Materials

A proper subfloor is essential for any flooring installation. Our calculator helps you determine the exact materials needed for plywood, OSB, fasteners, and underlayment.

Subfloor Material Options

Material Pros Cons Best Use
Plywood Strong, stable, moisture resistant More expensive Premium installations
OSB Cost effective, strong Less moisture resistant Dry environments
AdvanTech Superior moisture resistance Higher cost Wet areas, basements
ZIP System Integrated moisture barrier Premium pricing New construction

Thickness Requirements by Joist Spacing

Joist Spacing Minimum Thickness Recommended Heavy Loads
12" OC ¬Ω" ‚Öù" ¬æ"

24" OC 1‚Öõ" 1‚Öõ" 1‚Öú"

Installation Guidelines

  • Stagger Joints: Offset panel joints for maximum strength
  • Gap Spacing: Leave ‚Öõ" gaps between panels for expansion
  • Fastener Spacing: 6" on edges, 8-12" in field depending on thickness
  • Adhesive: Use construction adhesive for squeakless floors
  • Moisture Protection: Seal cut edges in moisture-prone areas

Fastener Requirements

  • Screws: 1¬º" minimum length, 2¬Ω" for thick subfloors
  • Nails: Ring shank or spiral nails, 8d minimum
  • Spacing: 6" on perimeter, 8-12" in field
  • Pilot Holes: Pre-drill near edges to prevent splitting

Subfloor Calculator FAQ

What thickness subfloor do I need?

Thickness depends on joist spacing: ‚Öù" minimum for 16" spacing, ¬æ" recommended. Use 1‚Öõ" for 24" spacing or heavy loads.

Should I use screws or nails for subfloor?

Screws are recommended for their holding power and ability to be removed. Use 1¬º" minimum length for ¬æ" subfloor.

Do I need underlayment over plywood subfloor?

Depends on your finish flooring. Hardwood and tile typically don't need it. Laminate and engineered floors often do.

How much waste should I add for subfloor materials?

Add 10% for simple rectangular rooms, 15% for complex shapes or if you're inexperienced with cutting.
